Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2011 11:13AM Laura5 wrote: Hello everyone, Just want to tell everyone who has not started chemo yet about cold cap therapy. I just finished 6 rounds of TCH with all of my hair. I am so thrilled and just want to make sure everyone knows that they do have an option when it comes to losing their hair. I know that this has given me a much more positive attitude throughout my chemo, as well as letting me keep my privacy.  I used Penguin Cold Caps-   www.msc-worldwide.com

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2011 02:12PM Laura5 wrote: Bapen, I would be happy to answer any questions you have about cold caps. I am so happy I used them. I still can't believe I am done with chemo and have all of my hair.

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2012 07:41AM Laura5 wrote: Abbey20, First of all, no one knows why certain women (and men) get breast cancer. There are many women on these boards who did everything right, did nothing that supposedly carried a bc risk, but here they are, just the same. I asked my doctors this question as well, and they said the same thing, so please don't ever feel guilty. My oncologist at Mayo Clinic where I had my surgery, as well as my oncologist closer to home where I had chemo,  told me that with the discovery of Herceptin, those of us who are Her2+, have the same if not slightly better odds. Chemo is no fun, but really only 4 yucky feeling days each round for me. They have drugs for nausea, and I used cold caps to keep my hair, which made me feel in control of at least one thing. I finished chemo in Dec. and will have my last Herceptin on Thursday, YAY! Herceptin has been a non-issue for me, and I think for the majority of women as well. You are at the hardest part of this right now. It will get easier.

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2012 04:52PM Laura5 wrote:  Bogie, My biopsi did not show her2+, so my plan was to have a lumpectomy and radiation. The tumor ended up testing her2+ so it was a big shock to hear chemo as part of my treatment. You need Herceptin to fight her2, and they don't recommend Herceptin alone. The cold caps worked like a miracle. I am done with chemo, and have all of my hair (on my head anyway). It is incredible. The website for the cold caps is  www.msc-worldwide.com . There is a thread on this website called Cold Cap Users, Past and Present if you are interested. kameli16, You sound like such a sweet daughter, you remind me of my own sweet daughters who have been a tremendous help to me throughout this. kenyohunt1, So sorry that you have to go through this again. You are not alone

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2011 04:52AM Laura5 wrote: tumnjun,You will be able to find out a lot more once your Mom's ER-PR-HER2 is known. That will determine treatment after surgery. Don't know where you live, but I recommend going to a really good hospital/cancer center for her surgery. If your Mom has to undergo chemo, and is concerned about hair loss, there is a cold cap system (Penguin Cold Caps) that you can use during chemo that will keep you from losing your hair. That is terrible that her boss/work is not being sympathetic. She does not need that added stress at this time. Her health needs to be her only concern right now. I think when you first hear that awful news-is the hardest. They will come up with a treatment plan it will get easier to cope. Your Mom is lucky to have you. Good Luck

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2011 05:29PM Laura5 wrote: Just want to let all of you know about cold cap therapy. I used Penguin Cold Caps and after 6 treatments of TCH, I still have all of my hair. I feel blessed that my daughter found out about these caps for me. I hated the thought of losing my hair and my privacy. If any of you are interested, the website is www.msc-worldwide.com. I will be glad to help anyone in any way I can. Good Luck!
Posts.Title: New... Jennt28 patty9999

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2011 06:36AM Laura5 wrote: bdavis,There have been recent studies showing that scalp mets with cold caps is less than one half  of 1%.  Yes, the caps are expensive, but well worth it to me. As far as being laborious, I wouldn't have traded it! My family and friends that were my cap helpers felt the same way. We had a good day of chatting and catching up every time and the day just flew by. My nurse, (who was not a cap fan) even admitted she thought the whole cap experience was why I had such a positive attitude throughout. I am sure all the cap users would agree with me.  Of course it is up to each person to decide if they want to use caps, but I have to tell you it was a really positive experience for me~and seeing hair on my head each day, allowing me to look like my old self as well as keep my privacy, was invaluable.

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2012 02:55PM Laura5 wrote: If you are willing to travel for the surgery, I would highly recommend Mayo Clinic in MN. We drove 6 1/2 hours and it was well worth it. They are amazing there, and are very accommodating to patients who have travelled a distance to get there. We had the initial trip there, and then one more trip a week or two later for follow-up. After my experience there, I wouldn't go anywhere else.

Posts.Title: Starting Chemo July 2013 Mellie289 JeriGrace

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2012 10:26PM Laura5 wrote: Camillia, I did not know anything about having a port versus not having one, but when my doctor talked about getting a port, I said "I'll pass" unless I have trouble with my veins. I could not stand the thought of one more procedure, or one more reminder. I wanted to be as much like my "normal" self as possible. I also chose to use cold caps to keep my hair. After 6 TC treatments and a year of Herceptin, my veins are fine, and I never lost my hair. I am very happy with my decisions. Good luck to you!

I went ahead with chemo, but I used cold caps and did not lose my hair. Good luck.
